results.adx_keywords: Vitamin D;Osteoporosis;Bones;Bone Fractures;Preventive Medicine;Clinical Trials;Research;Cummings, Steven R;Rosen, Clifford J;New England Journal of Medicine
results.title: Study Finds Another Condition That Vitamin D Pills Do Not Help
results.abstract: The vitamin pills do not prevent bone fractures in most people or protect against many other diseases, adding to questions about medical guidance many now take for granted.

media.caption: A study of nearly 26,000 people who were assigned to take vitamin D each day found the vitamin had no effect, even among people who had low vitamin D levels or osteoporosis.

results.title: The Default Tech Settings You Should Turn Off Right Away
results.abstract: These controls, which are buried inside products from Apple, Google, Meta and others, make us share more data than we need to.

results.title: On My 100th Birthday, Reflections on Archie Bunker and Donald Trump
results.abstract: The Emmy-winning TV producer Norman Lear considers his first century and his hopes for the next century.

media.caption: Carroll O’Connor, who played Archie Bunker, in 1971.

results.adx_keywords: Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare;Dogs;Research;Breeding of Animals;Humane Society of the United States;United States;Virginia
results.byline: By April Rubin and Jesus Jiménez
results.title: 4,000 Mistreated Beagles Need Homes. These Folks Are Stepping Up.
results.abstract: The dogs were headed for testing labs and didn’t even have names or know how to play. Volunteers are introducing them to grassy yards and cuddly movie nights for the first time.
org_facet: Humane Society of the United States

media.caption: “Everything, from the way that grass feels to watching cars drive by, it’s all going to be a brand-new experience for them,” said Lindsay Hamrick of the Humane Society of the United States.

results.adx_keywords: Railroads;Travel and Vacations;Amtrak;Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art;Albany (NY);Berkshires (Mass);Jacksonville (Fla);Lenox (Mass);Manhattan (NYC)
results.title: Ditching the Car and Enjoying the View on a Trip to the Berkshires
results.abstract: For the first time in 50 years, a weekend train route is taking passengers directly from New York to the Berkshires. The Berkshire Flyer will run through Labor Day. Good luck getting a seat.

media.caption: The Berkshire Flyer, a new train route between New York City and Pittsfield, Mass., began service in July. It’s one of many new services and restored rail lines that Amtrak has announced in recent months.
media.copyright: Tara Donne for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: War and Armed Conflicts;Russian Invasion of Ukraine (2022);Art;Museums;Social Media;Culture (Arts);Books and Literature;Jefferson, Margo;Rubens, Peter Paul;Zelensky, Volodymyr;Tokarczuk, Olga;Borodianka (Ukraine);Kyiv (Ukraine);Ukraine
results.title: The Role of Art in a Time of War
results.abstract: Painting will not stop missiles. Music will not end suffering. But culture is not powerless — and a visit to Ukraine reaffirmed what it can do at its best.

results.adx_keywords: Pilates;Health Clubs;Exercise;Physical Therapy;Pain;Muscles
results.title: Is Pilates as Good as Everyone Says?
results.abstract: The strength and flexibility workout is having a moment. What can — and can’t — it do for us?

media.copyright: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times

results.byline: By Noah Weiland and Sharon LaFraniere
results.title: Biden Administration Plans to Offer Updated Booster Shots in September
results.abstract: With reformulated shots from Pfizer and Moderna on the horizon, the F.D.A. has decided that Americans under 50 should wait to receive second boosters.
org_facet: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

media.caption: The new versions are expected to perform better against the now-dominant Omicron subvariant BA.5, although the data available so far is still preliminary.
media.copyright: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times

results.title: Prague Gets a Reset and the Emphasis Is Local
results.abstract: Public spaces, provocative exhibitions, new restaurants and unexpected neighborhoods offer visitors a deeper look into Czech culture.

media.caption: New arrivals include the food court Manifesto Market’s stylish Anděl branch.

results.byline: By Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
results.title: Surprise Deal Would Be Most Ambitious Climate Action Undertaken by U.S.
results.abstract: The announcement Wednesday of an agreement in the Senate almost instantly reset the role of the United States in the global effort to fight climate change.

media.caption: The climate legislation’s most immediate effect will be to supercharge the growth of wind and other clean energy industries in the United States, experts said.
media.copyright: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times

results.abstract: How fines and fees trap people in a kind of penury from which they may never escape.

results.adx_keywords: Doctors;Abortion;States (US);Pregnancy and Childbirth;Sex Crimes;Law and Legislation;Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision);Attorneys General;Bernard, Caitlin;Indiana
results.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Ava Sasani
results.title: An Indiana Doctor Speaks Out on Abortion, and Pays a Price
results.abstract: Dr. Caitlin Bernard, who provided an abortion to a 10-year-old, says doctors shouldn’t be silent. But she finds herself at the center of a post-Roe clash shaking the medical community.

media.caption: Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an Indianapolis obstetrician-gynecologist, gained national attention for providing abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim.
media.copyright: Amanda Andrade-Rhoades for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Earth;Greenhouse Gas Emissions;Global Warming;Air Pollution;Deaths (Obituaries);Lovelock, James E
results.title: James Lovelock, Whose Gaia Theory Saw the Earth as Alive, Dies at 103
results.abstract: A British ecologist, he captured imaginations with his hypothesis and was essential to today’s understanding of man-made pollutants and their effect on the climate.

media.caption: James Lovelock in 1962. Among his inventions was the Electron Capture Detector, an inexpensive, portable, exquisitely sensitive device used to measure the spread of toxic man-made compounds in the environment.

results.adx_keywords: Travel and Vacations;Restaurants;Bars and Nightclubs;Hotels and Travel Lodgings;Museums;Architecture;Content Type: Service;Bourse de Commerce (Paris, France);Louvre Museum;Musee d'Orsay;Paris (France)
results.title: In Paris, Grand Openings and Gourmet Meals Await
results.abstract: Big spaces and boldface names lead a stylish comeback for the City of Light. “We’re looking at a lovely year,” one chef says.

media.caption: Housed in the centuries-old building that was once Paris’s stock exchange, the Bourse de Commerce-Collection Pinault museum was renovated by the Japanese architect Tadao Ando. It is one of many cultural institutions that opened in Paris over the past two years.
media.copyright: Joann Pai for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Oceans and Seas;Fish and Other Marine Life;Exploration and Explorers;Science and Technology;Earth;National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration;Atlantic Ocean;Azores Islands
results.title: There Are Holes on the Ocean Floor. Scientists Don’t Know Why.
results.abstract: Similar openings on the sea floor were first spotted 18 years ago along the Mid-Atlantic Ridge. Their origins remain unknown. Scientists are asking the public for their thoughts.

media.caption: While researchers explored a volcano in the Mid-Atlantic Ridge on July 23, they observed several sets of holes in the sediment that remain a mystery to scientists.

results.title: The Life and Death of Daniel Auster, a Son of Literary Brooklyn
results.abstract: Memorably depicted in his father’s books, he struggled with drug addiction through a life that put him close to a notorious murder and came to an end in a family tragedy.

results.adx_keywords: Content Type: Personal Profile;Baseball;Sporting Goods and Equipment;Soil;audio-neutral-immersive;audio-positive-escape;audio-positive-nostalgic;Major League Baseball;Delaware River;New Jersey
results.title: He’s Baseball’s Only Mud Supplier. It’s a Job He May Soon Lose.
results.abstract: Jim Bintliff collects the Delaware River mud that is smeared on Major League baseballs to make them less slippery. But that tradition is in jeopardy.

media.caption: Jim Bintliff and his family have been selling Delaware River mud to Major League Baseball for decades. Here, he fills a bucket in New Jersey.
media.copyright: Hannah Beier for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Deaths (Obituaries);Photography;Wrestling;Masks;Grobet, Lourdes;Mexico
results.title: Lourdes Grobet, Photographer of Mexico’s Masked Wrestlers, Dies at 81
results.abstract: In her innovative career, she found her ultimate subject in lucha libre wrestling: men and women who, to her, were members of an unexplored subculture.

media.caption: “La Venus,” 1985. The photographer Lourdes Grobet was known for her images of the masked wrestlers, both men and women, in the Mexican sport lucha libre.
